reviewText: First off, this is not the first "Farm" series the BBC has done with these 3 historians.  This is actually the 3'd in a whole unique series!If you're interested in going in order, I urge you to check out "Tales From The Green Valley" (set in the 1620's), *& mini companion "A Tudor Feast" (1500/1600 at Haddon Hall), Victorian Farm *& supplementary companion: Victorian Pharmacy starring Ruth Goodman*.  There is also 2 more series after "Edwardian Farm".  "Wartime Farm" (WWII era), and one that is currently being aired in the UK called "Tudor Monastery Farm" (w/ Ruth & Peter, but minus Alex).My hats off to the BBC for creating such a fascinating, and informative historical reality series!Truthfully there's hardly anything to compare it to in the US.  PBS has aired 3 (US filmed) series of this genre a few years back from three different periods: "Colonial House" (1620's), "Frontier House" (1880's), and "Texas Ranch House" (late 1860's).  While good in themselves, I've much preferred ones produced by the BBC.The farm series takes you a whole year into every aspect of farm life at the time.  Utilizing modern technology/tools along the way.  They have various extra historians, and experts of certain fields as guests too.  You learn so much about a person's daily of the era, that it's as if you're transported back in time!  There's animal husbandry, gardening, homemade remedies, recipes;  even the origin of certain sayings, and other educational tidbits!  The historians are super informative, and I applaud them for taking such time and effort to really learn all aspects of the time period they're delving into.In conclusion, if you love history, and wonder what it was really like to live in the past-- I highly recommend this documentary miniseries, and again, all the rest that I mentioned above!
summary: The BBC Takes Historical Documenting To Whole New Heights In This Fascinating Farm Series!

reviewText: After serially watching The Victorian Farm, The Victorian Pharmacy, and The Edwardian Farm, I am starting to feel like that fire-haired dynamo Ruth Goodman is a personal friend. The woman is tirelessly cheerful and perpetually awesome! In Edwardian clothing she cooks, she cleans, she sews, she farms, she scrubs, she orates upon subjects far and wide, and to top it all off, she fearlessly tosses modesty away and strips down to her glowing naked pinkness in order to bathe in front of us and show us how it used to be done! Is there anything she won't do in the name of education? I think not! (I now feel so close to her having seen most of her left breast, I'll tell ya what!) Everything Ruth stars in is brilliant but The Edwardian Farm is her magnum opus. That daring duo of Alex Langlands and Peter Ginn are her patient comrades in this living history extravaganza that depicts how it was to dwell in one corner of southwest England circa 1905. We see a mining enterprise, farming, market gardening, a fishery, household chores, social outings, EVERYTHING as it would have been in the golden years between Victoria's death and the great cultural ream-out that was the First World War. While The Edwardian Farm is LONG and sometimes SLOW, it is always interesting, frequently exciting, and even sometimes funny, especially when Ruth cackles that throaty madwoman laugh of hers. This also happens to be one of the prettiest series ever done. The skies are a shocking cloudless blue, the wildflowers on Dartmoor are unearthly, and the shots of the goings on in this pastoral river town make you want to pause and stare...My friends, I have not one bad thing to say about The Edwardian Farm. Nope, not one!
summary: This Is What Reality TV Was Made For!

reviewText: Love it.Anyone who likes anything to do with history, old England, beautiful old buildings, countryside or a simpler (?) way of life will enjoy this.  It takes you thru the ins and outs and trying to make a living on a farm at the turn of the 20th century in England.Some things really are surprising.  All in all, a great 12 hours of information and enjoyment.

reviewText: Edwardian Farm is what I wanted Manor House; (Regency House Party, & etc.) to be. I want to get the feel of the era.I suspect I'm not the only person who chafes at the "modern duck" out of water stories that most of these re-creations turn out to be. And forget anything coming out of American television--short of PBS. (and even then...) Why do we not educate our people with our tv programs the way the Brits do? I have had to turn to the BBC often enough that I catch myself using Briticisms...in my thought processes!!I ran into Edwardian Farm on YouTube, and became so engrossed that I purchased an all region DVD player and payed a small fortune to purchase the series on DVD. I have also purchasedVictorian Farm - Complete Series - 2-DVD Set [ NON-USA FORMAT, PAL, Reg.2 Import - United Kingdom] and am saving my dollars to buy the hard-backed books that were created for the series.American producers: Instead of shelling out the tiny bucks for some mindless "reality series" or remaking some great film, take a lesson from the BBC and give us something worth watching!

reviewText: I am not finished watching this series yet, but I thought there might be people out there who would appreciate a better idea of what to expect before investing their time and money.This team of two male archaeologists and a female historian have done several similar projects, where they recreate a period homestead using resources that would have been available at the time.  This is the first series that has been released on DVD in the U.S.  The Edwardian farm is in the village of Morwellham Quay in Devon, on the banks of the River Tamar. Following traditional roles, the men (Alex and Peter) busy themselves in the fields, while the woman (Ruth) occupies herself turning the house into a home (mostly - there is a bit of overlap, usually pretty amusing).  It is a documentary with voice-over narration, and it's fascinating.It's particularly satisfying that they bring in locals who are experts on some of these centuries-old processes - repairing a hedgerow, building a fish hatchery, producing quicklime, mining copper and tin, celebrating an authentic Edwardian Halloween, forging farm implements.  In March they bring in a Tennessee horse trainer to help out with their new Dartmoor pony.  It's fun and awe-inspiring at the same time.Ruth's resources are mostly books from the period, cookbooks and how-to books.  She makes a rag rug, cooks sheeps head stew, uses all-natural cleaning products, and in truly heroic fashion, restores the privy.The trio (often accompanied by Ruth's daughter Eve) spend a calendar year at the farm, beginning in September.  Each month is an hour-long episode.  The set contains 4 discs, each one corresponding to a season beginning with autumn.I will update the review as I continue watching.  At this point I'm completely hooked, so it shouldn't be too long.  This is a glimpse into history with obvious effort taken to maintain authenticity.  The dynamic between Peter, Alex and Ruth is easygoing and somewhat familial.  It's really enjoyable, highly recommended.Update 8/19/13 - I have now finished watching this series.  I enjoyed it thoroughly and will watch it again.  Incidents in the Edwardian year keep occurring to me - I have mentioned this CD several times in the course of conversation and will be sharing it with family and friends.I particularly appreciate the willingness of Peter, Alex and Ruth to immerse themselves completely in the period.  Perhaps when the cameras were turned off, they may have taken shortcuts or used modern technology, but there is no doubt in my mind that they were committed to experiencing life as the Edwardians did (and as Ruth points out, it was often a hard life).  I would love it if some of their other ventures (World War I Farm, Victorian Farm) were made available in the US.

reviewText: This show is wonderful. My family and I really enjoy watching it. This show is different from other reenactment dramas because the characters choose to be there and are quite game at trying new stuff. (In other BBC reenactment dramas sometimes the characters are unwilling and complain nearly all the time).I like all the people and really got the feel of what it would be like to live in Edwardian times. I'm a bit surprised the other shows in this series like Victorian Farm were never ported to US region 1 DVD's. But no worries, I bought a copy on eBay and a regionless DVD player so I can watch the British version at home without dealing with the fuss of regions...I recommend people try this This is a good show, and well worth watching.
